body_text.text: The book includes all the papers delivered at an international Conference in Augusta, Michigan, April 21-23, 1976 . The editor, Dr.A. Bouhuys, has provided a very helpful format with three different parts: (i) cells in the normal lung, (2) mechanisms of lung disease and (3) impact on lung disease research.

The selection of speakers and papers was well prepared, so that the goal of the conference and hence of this book is fully achieved: to assemble a multidisciplinary group of people presenting, interpreting and discussing data and ideas on lung cells in the normal and diseased lung. This book certainly is not only valuable to the participants in the symposium; the articles cover subjects of great interest to all specialists in lung diseases, whether they are oriented toward patients or research.

Clinicians will be fascinated by insights into the results of modern research that are the basis of diagnosis and therapy. Research scientists from different backgrounds will find excellent reviews of the subjects, detailed data on methods and, at the end of each article, an exhaustive bibliography containing articles difficult to find elsewhere.

The quality of the presentation and of the reproductions of electron micrographs is excellent. All the authors raise many questions to be answered and indicate possibilities for future research. This contributes to our impression that the book will be of value in the years to come. During the first half of this century, the spectacular effect of antibiotics on infectious lung diseases, including tuberculosis, had an unexpected result: very little attention was devoted by experimental scientists to lung structure and function. However, the increase of life expectancy in Western societies brought about a readjustment in the attitude of those involved in planning medical research. It became increasingly evident that chronic obstructive lung diseases, such as chronic bronchitis, emphysema and progressive fibrosis of professional or environmental origin are responsible for a significant fraction of morbidity and mortality in these societies. It was also realized that no significant advancement in our understanding of these diseases was possible without detailed knowledge of the biochemistry and cellular biology of the lung. Only a reinterpretation of lung structure and function in terms of modern matrix biology and cell behavior could lead to a better understanding of the above-mentioned diseases. The decision, in 1972, of the Heart and Lung Institute of the National Institutes of Health, followed by several European research establishments, to foster basic lung research surely played an important role in the recent increase in interest on the part of biochemists in lung structure and function. It became urgent therefore to produce a comprehensive monograph series on "Lung Biology in Health and Disease" to help scientists start original investigations in what was considered a "no-man's-land" a decade ago. Dr. Claude Lenfant, of the National Institutes of Health, has undertaken this important task.

The present volume is the second in this series and is probably the most eagerly awaited and valuable one for connective tissue biochemists who have acquired a recent interest in this field, as well as for lung pathologists not yet familiar with modern matrix biology. To present a comprehensive treatise on such a complex problem was not an easy venture, however.

It had to take into account the recent and important developments in our understanding of the structural and dynamic aspects of matrix biology as well as the specific needs of specialists dealing with lung composition, structure and pathology. Dr. Ronald Crystal has successfully met this challenge by producing a concise yet sufficiently detailed monograph on the basic biochemistry of pulmonary function. The editor and his team have acquired a solid reputation in pulmonary connective tissue biochemistry, and this is certainly the best qualification for a valid presentation of this rapidly growing branch of science. Dr. Crystal is also to be congratulated for having chosen competent contributors to the volume as well as for not having dissociated the cellular and molecular aspects of lung chemistry.

Part I of the book is devoted to the cells of the lung. The first chapter, by Charles Kuhn, is on "The Cells of the Lung and their Organelles" and gives a comprehensive review of the morphological and functional definition of the different cell types of the lung and airways. The second chapter, by G. Gould, Jr., deals with the methods of preparation of lung cell suspensions that are useful for morphological or cell culture studies. Part II of the book deals with "The Basic Metabolic Functions of the Lung. " Oxygen utilization and energy production are described by Aron B. Fisher; glucose metabolism, by Donald F. Tierney and Steven E. Levey; lipid metabolism, by Robert J. Mason; protein synthesis, by James F. Collin and Ronald G. Crystal.

Part III is devoted to "The Connective Tissue of the Lung. " Collagen biochemistry is amply described by Allan J. Hance and Ronald G. Crystal; proteoglycans and elastic fibers are discussed in a more compact form by Allen L. Horowitz, Norton A. Elson and Ronald G. Crystal; and -l-antitrypsin as a systemic determination of lung structure and function is described in detail by Allan E. Cohen. Part IV concerns "The Surfactant System of Lung. " Its composition is described by John A. Clernents and Richard J. King; its synthesis and intracellular transport and secretion, by Donald Massaro and Gloria D. Massaro.
In Part V of the book, a stimulating and intelligent effort is made by Jack D. Fulmer and Ronald G. Crystal to integrate biochemistry with the structure and function of the lung.

All these chapters are competently written and well illustrated. The difficult task of offering an up-to-date, easily understandable picture to students of different disciplines and of showing the relevance of such data for lung biochemistry and pathology is well accomplished. In all likelihood, therefore, this book will prove very useful in the many laboratories actively engaged all over the world in lung research. Reading this book one is deeply impressed by the knowledge of viral diseases gathered during the last few decades. More impressive still are the gaps in our knowledge that are pointed out by the authors on each page. This book, covering 584 pages, fills a need that, notwithstanding the steady flow of handbooks, textbooks and monographs which have appeared during the last few years, has not yet been met. All the contributing authors present their subject in a clear way and follow practical, uniform subdivisions, which makes the book readily accessible despite its sfze.

Physicians with a special interest in lung diseases will find ample information in this book. More than one quarter of the contents deals with viral infections of the respiratory system. Besides clinical manifestations of adenovirus, corona virus, influenza, parainfluenzaj respiratory syncytial virus, rhinovirus and other incidental virus infections, special attention is given to aspects of epiderniology, control and prevention. The subtitle of the book is therefore relevant. The biological characteristics of the various viruses are described only if they interfere with the epidemiological pattern of the viral infection.

After going through the subsequent chapters, the reader is not inclined to have an overly optimistic view of the possibilities of combating respirazory diseases of viral origin. This is due to the fact that at this moment there clearly is no therapy for viral diseases. Moreover, in terms of prevention and prophylaxis, problems arise that differ profoundly, even within certain virus groups, for instance the myxoviruses.

The way in which most of the authors handle topical questions in virology will certainly be all the more reason for physicians interested in respiratory disease to have Viral Infections of Humans within reach. Rapidly advancing developments in medicine have necessitated multiauthored textbooks in all subspecialities, and pulmonary medicine is no exception. In this first edition, the editors have limited their co-authors to six, thus improving the usual time lag in publication andj also, interauthor communication. Repetition is scarce and the text concentrates on current concepts in both physiology and clinical disease. The bibliography is up-to-date and well chosen; each chapter has references from 1975 and 1976. Divided into two parts, the text begins with a challenging chapter on pulmonary physiology. Air pollution, environmental hazards and variations in atmospheric conditions are discussed without belaboring the details of experimental conditions. Pulmonary anatomy is not mentioned; however, the reader is referred to the standard anatomy texts. Emphasis is placed on the physiologic importance of the ventilation-perfusion relationship and the use of flow-volume curves. Part If, dealing with clinical pulmonary disease, offers a balanced mixture of history and epidemiology plus sound guidelines for practical management.

The chapter dealing with respiratory failure is quite good. While certain newer advances in clinical pulmonary disease have been neglectede. g., discussions of the sleep-apnea syndrome, upper airway obstruction, or the biochemical enzymes that are of assistance in the management of patients with sarcoidosis -the book does contain important chapters regarding the management of patients with chest trauma and during the preand postoperative period.

The book is recommended for those with an interest in chest disease, whether as general internist, chest physician or chest surgeon. The reasonable (by today's standard) price will also make the book available to medical students and respiratory therapists. Both the physiology and clinical pulmonary sections are accurate and easily readable~ also, the work is well indexed, which makes it easy to use. This text is a welcome addition to the field of pulmonary medicine and should be available in every hospital library. The role of the immune system is to protect against micro-organisms and to preserve the integrity of the body by reacting with foreign antigenic material. Such protective immune reactions may cause damage to host tissues through the formation of complexes between foreign antigens and antibodies, by stimulating reaginic antibodies or killer T cells -thus provoking various allergic r.eactions -or by abolishing tolerance leading to autoimmunity. The lung is expected to be particularly exposed to such reactions because inhaled foreign material may come into close contact with immunocompetent cells and antibodies in the lung tissue, where it may cause hypersensitivity reactions of various kinds. In addition, the high vascularity of the organ makes it a common target for blood-borne immune reactions which damage systemic tissue. The clinical consequences of a deficient immune defense are particularly severe for the lungs when pneumonia and bronchiectasies, in particular those caused by bacterial infections, are commonly encountered in chronic antibody deficiency syndromes. Infections with micro-organisms such as Pneumocystis carinii, viruses and fungi are problems in patients with deficiencies of cell-mediated immunity. For pneumologists who have patients with immunological problems in their everyday practice, it is important to keep in touch with progress in immunology of lung diseases. This task may be served by the recent comprehensive and up-to-date review of clinical and experimental immunology of lung disorders given in Immunologic and Infectious Reactions in the Lung. The book contains 24 chapters written by recognized experts. It is sparsely illustrated with well-selected figures.

The first part covers various aspects of the immune defense system in the lung. Immune mechanisms in infections with Mycoplasma pneumoniae, syncytial viruses and Pseudomonas are presented separately in excellent reviews. The second part includes immunodeficiency, drug hypersensitivity, asthma and other immune-damaging diseases of the lung. A chapter is devoted to eosinophilia of the lung, which is given a thorough review. In the third part the present status of prophylaxis and treatment of infectious and allergic lung diseases is reviewed.

The potential future use of lung transplantation and transfer factor treatment in lung diseases is also discussed. An important chapter concerns genetic factors in atopic allergic diseases. The book also contains an 80-page chapter by E.R. Weibel and J. Gil on structure-function relations in the alveoli. This piece goes beyond Weibel's 1973 review article but repeats much previously published material from his group.

The remaining chapters are of less interest. The one on lung mechanics (F. G. Hoppin, Jr. , and J. Hildebrandt) is difficult to read and seems unfinished; their writing is unclear. For example (p. 88), "... at a given transpulmonary pressure, the volume is higher during deflation than during inflation and is higher the higher the volume from which inflation or deflation was started. " The chapter on kinetics of 0 2 and CO 2 exchange (E. P. Hill, G.G. Power and L.D. Longo) is largely based on papers published by these authors in 1973 but contains some additional predictions and interpretations from their mathematical model. I found the piece on control of ventilation (F. S. Grodins and S. M. Yamashiro) disappointing.
Like several other chapters, it deals with mathematical models but does not clearly show how they have improved our understanding of the physiological mechanisms.
The authors admit that "hyperpnea of exercise and the integration of 'chemical control of ventilation' with 'neural control of the respiratory cycle' " are unsolved problems.
I believe these will be solved, not by

TABREF4.text: John B. West, ed. (Lung Biology in Health and Disease, Vol. 3). 583 pages. Illus. New York and Basel: MarcelDekker, Inc., 1977. ~ 55.00. This book is a collection of individual essay, with no attempt to tie them together. They are written for physiologists and others who want detailed discussions beyond the scope of the usual scientific article. There are two main reasons for buying it, in spite of the high price. First, the chapters on airflow in the airways (T. J. Pedley, R.C. Schroter and M.F. Sudlow) and on blood flow in the pulmonary capillaries (Y. B. Fung and S.S. Sobin) are comprehensive discussions of those topics. Second, the chapter by J.B. West and P.D. Wagneris a detailed description of these authors' work on ventilation-perfusion relations and contains many technical details not available elsewhere.
